title: Alarm at ASX's blockchain armageddon
text:
When you combine this centralised power with the ASX’s Holder Identification Number, which is equivalent to an ASX-controlled custodian business, there is the opportunity for the ASX to be at the core of all share trading administration and execution.

Anyone who owns shares and has a bank account could well find the ASX is the most cost-efficient platform for buying and selling shares in real time. This might not happen until 2025, but it is potentially part of the new share trading paradigm.

As the armageddon-like implications of the blockchain/DLT technology have become more obvious, a range of market participants have turned to Canberra for help. Their primary concern is the potential for ASX to entrench its market power without sufficient regulatory oversight.

A group calling itself the CHESS Replacement Stakeholder Group has been lobbying the office of the Treasurer Josh Frydenberg, the office of the Finance Minister Mathias Cormann, the chairman of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services, James Patterson, and Shadow Treasurer Jim Chalmers.

The stakeholder group’s founding members are the Australian Investor Relations Association, Governance Institute of Australia, Australian Shareholders Association, Stockbrokers and Financial Advisers Association, Link Group, BoardRoom and Computershare.

The group wants the federal government to accelerate the implementation of legislation that would allow the Council of Financial Regulators to enforce “appropriate parameters around the ASX’s use of its monopoly powers”.

Additionally, the group wants “a parliamentary review to examine the scope, consultation and industry impacts of ASX’s CHESS replacement program”.

Ian Matheson, the chief executive of AIRA, and Governance Institute chief executive Megan Motto told Chanticleer they believed federal politicians had been “sucked in” by ASX’s presentations about its contribution to capital raising.

“The ASX continues with a charade of consultation on CHESS but it’s them talking to the stakeholders with no acknowledgement of our concerns over a long period of time,” Matheson said.

“There is no enforcement powers in the hand of regulators to stop the ASX from abusing its market power at some time in the future,” Motto said.

Disruptive power

Stevens told Chanticleer he was in Canberra last week with the ASX board of directors to provide a regular update on the CHESS replacement for federal government ministers, senior public servants and members of the opposition.

His presentation did not back away from the disruptive power of the DLT/blockchain functionality of the new system. It said about $22.4 billion in costs associated with administering the superannuation system could be slashed by removing legacy systems and building innovative services.

Stevens’ three punchlines in his presentation to the politicians were as follows: some may not like information to be more freely available; some currently benefit from fragmented, siloed and inconsistent sources of truth; and some currently benefit from information delays allowing money to sit idle.

Stevens said the five main complaints made by the stakeholder group included many untruths.

First, he said the federal government has opened up clearing and settlement to competition and it is possible a competitor will emerge.

Advertisement

Second, he said it was not true that consultation had been “fragmented and ineffective”. He said there had been 17 ASX business committee meetings, 26 technical committee meetings, 20 webinars, five monthly newsletters, 35 industry working groups, 7549 emails sent responding to questions, 455 pages of technical documentation published, three out of seven software releases delivered to market and monthly meetings with the securities regulator, the central bank, the competition regulator and Treasury.

“This is a company that is actually investing and actually creating jobs and believes in technology, believes in the future, and believes that's a good thing for the country,” he said.

Stevens believes the critics are turning the DLT/blockchain element of the CHESS replacement into some sort of “voodoo”.

“It’s actually updating software, updating hardware, updating security, updating functionality, updating messaging and also saying to the industry, we're not going to take more data,” he said.

“We're not going to charge you any more money. We're going to pay for the capital expenditure. It would be remiss of us not to put it in a distributed ledger at the bottom, because if we're building a technology system for the next 20, 30 years, you may have made a massive mistake in five years when you look back and say we haven’t done this.”

Chanticleer understands the government has privately indicated to industry that it supports the ASX blockchain replacement for CHESS on the basis that if the ASX gets it right, not only will it be good for the ASX, it will be good for Australia.
description: As the ASX moves towards the pointy end of replacing Australia’s equity clearing and settlement system it is suddenly dawning on a range of market participants that their businesses could disappear.
